bibl.title: Letter from T.H.D. Griffitts to Henry Rose Carter, April 23, 1923

div1.p: Griffitts writes that he was not chosen for International Health Board work. He offers his opinion on employee-Health Service relations.

div1.head: Letter from T.H.D. Griffitts to Henry Rose Carter, April 23, 1923
div1.opener:
N. M. C.
Griffitts
OFFICE OF
MALARIA INVESTIGATIONS
TREASURY DEPARTMENT
UNITED STATES
PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE
MEMO TEMA
519 Dexter Avenue,
Montgomery, Alabama,
April 23, 1923.
Dear Doctor Carter:
div1.p:
Things happen strangely. I was writing your name on the wrapping of
the Watson book in returning it to you, when your letter was brought in
yhis morning
this morning. It has gone forward to you--registered.

Lucky Louis! Several months ago, my name was suggested to the I.H.B.
in connection with their proposed work in that country. I told Mr. Rose
that I was very much interested. As for the Service, however, I don't
believe I will ever get a chance to do anything but work-- handicapped
by not being a “regular” l l. I should like to have gone on this detail,
but am particularly pleased that Louis was the one selected.

Yes; I called on Henry when in Birmingham about a month ago. I had
met him a year ago and found him a delightful fellow--just as I had
quite naturally expected to find him. I shall see him again soon
and want to avail myself of your good offer about the volume of P. of M.
of
of T.

I thank you very much for the use of the Watson's so long. If the
Service would do like other countries and send its men out oftener to
see what the rest of the world is doing, we'd get somewhere surer, and
perhaps sometime would detail men according to their fitness, rather than
from rank, etc. If a man knows work, or if he is intelligently interseted
enough to learn it, that's what he should be assigned to.

I am leaving in a few minutes for Dale county, and among other things
over
I expect to get by blood examinations somewhat of a check on the efficacy
of quinine use around a bad pond-- the Newton pond, where about seventy
per cent of the people had malaria last year. They were given the standard
treatment last Fall. All cases now should be of last years infection, or
previous infections. While at the dam a short time ago, out of three
five or six men standing around. I got blood from three. All were positive,
two carried gametocytes and one had both AE and Ter. This case had AE rings,
schizonts, crescents and tertian gametocytes. And he is supposed to have had
standard treatment. This is a sample, but I hope it does not hold out for
the rest of the population!
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, T.H.D. Griffitts
Epidemiologist. Answered April 26
